Graphical abstract Co-precipitated ZnO/Cr2O3 catalyst precursors were thermally pretreated in synthetic air (calcination), N2 (pyrolysis) and 10% H2 diluted in N2 (reduction) at temperatures in the range from 320°C to 600°C and then applied in methanol synthesis from CO and H2 at 260–300°C and 60bar. The X-ray diffraction patterns showed that increasing temperatures used in the thermal pretreatment lead to sintering of both the resulting non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel and ZnO phases. However, reduced and pyrolyzed catalysts exhibit a much slower increase in particle size of the Zn-Cr spinel phase compared with the calcined catalyst. Correspondingly, at the same temperature of thermal pretreatment the specific surface areas of the catalyst follow the trend reduced catalyst>pyrolyzed catalyst>calcined catalyst. Chromate species were found to be present in the calcined catalyst, while their amount decreased with increasing calcination temperature. Infrared spectroscopy and temperature-programmed reduction confirmed the existence of carbonate species in the catalysts reduced or pyrolyzed below 500°C. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption showed that the calcined catalysts exhibit more acid sites due to the existence of chromate species. The reduced and pyrolyzed catalysts demonstrate significantly improved performance in high-temperature methanol synthesis compared with the calcined catalysts, and the maximum methanol productivity was achieved subsequent to reduction at 500°C. It is suggested that the thermal pretreatment in reducing or inert atmosphere favors the formation of oxygen vacancies, which are considered to be the active sites for the hydrogenation of CO. Keywords ZnO/Cr2O3 Methanol synthesis Oxygen vacancies Thermal pretreatment 1 Introduction Methanol is one of the most important platform chemicals in chemical industry because of its application in a wide range of fields [1,2]. Methanol synthesis from syngas produced by gasification of natural gas has been extensively studied for decades [3–6]. Recently, using biomass-derived syngas for the production of methanol has drawn considerable attention, since this process can be considered as utilizing renewable energy sources to generate alternative fuels [7]. However, biomass-derived syngas, which normally contains high levels of sulfur and nitrogen, is still facing a number of challenges in the purification process. Unlike Cu-based catalysts [8], ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts are stable against sulfur and halogen impurities and may provide an alternative for the conversion of biomass-derived syngas to methanol without expensive purification [9,10]. Furthermore, more and more industrially produced methanol is nowadays used for the methanol to olefin (MTO) process [11]. Considerable efforts have been made to merge methanol synthesis and MTO into one process by applying bifunctional catalysts consisting of a methanol synthesis catalyst and microporous acidic catalysts such as zeolites [12,13]. Considering both the kinetics and thermodynamics of the involved reactions, the direct conversion of syngas to olefins over the bifunctional catalysts is normally carried out at high temperatures around 400°C [12,13]. Due to their high thermal stability [14], ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts demonstrate higher potential as the methanol component of the bifunctional catalyst than Cu-based catalysts, which show significant sintering of the Cu nanoparticles at temperatures above 300°C [15]. Additionally, alkali-doped ZnO/Cr2O3 exhibits high productivity of isobutanol in HAS from syngas [16,17]. By optimizing the content of alkali metal, alkali-doped ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts can eventually be applied for the production of alcohol mixtures with optimal methanol/isobutanol ratio for the synthesis of MTBE [18–20]. Earlier investigations of ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts assumed ZnO to be the only active component. Cr2O3 was believed to promote the catalyst only via spinel formation, which prevented the sintering of the ZnO nanoparticles by providing a considerable large surface area improving their dispersion [14]. However, a later study showed that in the more active ZnO/Cr2O3 catalyst with high Zn:Cr ratio, the amount of detected ZnO is always lower than expected, suggesting ZnO possibly not to be the only active component in ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts [21]. Del Piero et al. [21] first proposed the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel containing an excess of Zn2+ ions formed by the dissolution of excess ZnO in ZnCr2O4 to be the main catalytically active phase. This hypothesis was further supported by extensive studies on the correlation between structure and activity of ZnO/Cr2O3 [22–26]. In addition, recent investigations on the alkali-doped ZnO/Cr2O3 catalyst for the synthesis of isobutanol from syngas revealed a linear correlation between isobutanol productivity and the level of cation disorder distribution caused by the formation of non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel, demonstrating the crucial role of non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel in the hydrogenation of CO to alcohols [16,27,28]. Since ZnO/Cr2O3 does not contain any metallic phases, it is generally accepted that oxygen vacancies are the actual active sites for the hydrogenation of CO. Our previous work showed that the co-precipitated catalyst with a Zn:Cr ratio of 65:35 exhibits the highest performance in methanol synthesis from CO and H2 [29]. This optimal Zn:Cr ratio corresponds to the stoichiometry of the hydrotalcite-like catalyst precursor Zn4Cr2(OH)12CO3 obtained by co-precipitation and is beneficial for the formation of the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel. DFT calculations showed that the energy required for the oxygen vacancy formation decreases with increasing content of Zn in the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel [29]. Given that non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel is mainly formed during the thermal treatment of the catalyst precursor, both the gas atmosphere and temperature applied in the thermal treatment can significantly influence the performance of the resulting ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts. In this work we focused on the determination of the optimal conditions of the thermal pretreatment and the correlation between the thermal pretreatment and the catalytic activity of ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts. The catalyst precursors with a Zn:Cr ratio of 65:35 were prepared by co-precipitation at a constant pH of 7. Subsequently, the hydrotalcite-like precursors were thermally treated at different temperatures in oxidizing atmosphere (synthetic air), inert atmosphere (pure N2) and reducing atmosphere (10% H2 diluted in N2), respectively. The resulting ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The catalytic activity of the catalysts in methanol synthesis was tested at 260–300°C and 60bar using a syngas mixture with a ratio of H2: CO=1.5 as feed stream. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The co-precipitation procedure of Kurtz et al. [30] was adapted for the synthesis of catalyst precursors with Zn:Cr=65:35. Metal salt solutions (1M) consisting of zinc and chromium nitrates were used as metal precursors. The co-precipitation was performed under continuous stirring at a constant pH of 7 by simultaneously adding Na2CO3 solution (1.2M) while the precipitation temperature was constantly kept at 65°C. The suspension after precipitation was aged at 65°C for 2h. Subsequently, the precipitate was filtered and washed with HPLC water and then dried for 18h at 120°C. In order to avoid the influence of possibly different Zn:Cr ratios of the precursor from different batches, all the catalyst precursors obtained were homogeneously mixed and finely ground prior to the thermal treatments. The dried precursors were annealed in synthetic air, N2 or 10% H2 diluted in N2 for 3h and the annealing temperature was varied from 320°C to 600°C. The catalysts were denoted as 65Zn-“gas atmosphere”-“applied temperature” 2.2 Characterization Optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) using an UNICAM PU 7000 was applied for the determination of the metal composition and the content of residual Na. Powder XRD was performed using a Panalytical MPD diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.154nm) at 45kV and 40mA without monochromator. The Kß emission line was suppressed using a Ni filter. Samples were measured with a continuous scan between 2θ=10–80° and a step size of 0.026° with 0.79s per step. The LeBail fitting using General Structure Analysis Software (GSAS) was applied to determine the lattice parameter. Qualitative phase analysis was carried out by using the X’Pert HighScore Plus software. The Powder diffraction files (PDF) of the International Center of Diffraction Data (ICDD) were used as the references. To determine the specific surface area of the samples, N2 physisorption was performed at 77K using a Quantachrome Autosorb-1-MP instrument. The samples were degassed under vacuum at 200°C for 2h prior to the measurement. Pore volume and average pore diameter were obtained using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. TPR was performed in a U-tube quartz reactor using a H2/Ar mixture containing 4.6% H2 as reducing agent. 100mg samples (250–355μm sieve fraction) were flushed with Ar to remove water and then reduced using a flow rate of 84.1ml/min. The temperature ramp was set to 5°C/min and monitored by a programmable temperature controller. The samples were heated to 800°C, and this temperature was held constant at 800°C for 1h. H2 consumption was measured by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Before the effluent gas entered the TCD, a cold trap filled with isopropanol and dry ice was used to remove water formed during reduction. For the NH3 TPD measurements, 100mg of samples was loaded in a U-tube reactor. The reactor was heated to 200°C for 3h to remove adsorbed water. After the reactor had been cooled to 100°C, a gas mixture of 5000ppm NH3 diluted in He was fed to the reactor at 100°C for 1h. Desorption was carried out by introducing a constant flow of He. The concentration of desorbing NH3 in the effluent gas stream was recorded by a non-dispersive IR detector. The temperature was increased to 320°C with a rate of 2°C/min and kept constant at 320°C for 3h. For some selected samples, the reactor temperature was further raised to 600°C for 1h. The SEM measurements were carried out using a FEI Quanta 4D FEG 600 equipped with a secondary electron detector. The energy of the electron beam was set to 20 keV. The samples for the SEM measurements were prepared by loosely dispersing the finely ground powder on conductive carbon tape. FTIR spectra were recorded using a Nicolet Nexus spectrometer and the KBr pressed-disc technique. The number of scans and the resolution were set to 64 and 4nm, respectively. For pressing the KBr discs, 150mg of KBr containing about 0.5wt% sample was loaded into a 15mm die set and pressed at 5 tons for 6min. XP spectra were acquired with an ultra-high vacuum set-up equipped with a high-resolution Gammadata-Scienta SES 2002 analyzer. Monochromatic Al Kα radiation was used (1486.6eV, anode operating at 14kV and 30mA). During the measurements the base pressure in the measurement chamber was kept at about 8×10−10 mbar. The CasaXPS software was used for the analysis of the XPS data. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalysts were tested in methanol synthesis using a 4-fold microreactor set-up described in detail in our previous work [29]. 500mg of catalyst with particle sizes of 250–355μm was loaded in each Silcosteel-AC reactor. No prereduction of the catalysts was performed prior to the catalytic tests. Methanol synthesis was carried out at 60bar using a mixture of 36% CO, 54% H2 and 10% N2 with a flow rate of 40ml/min resulting in a GHSV of 4800ml/(hgcat). The space velocity was carefully chosen to ensure that the degree of CO conversion is lower than the value at thermodynamic equilibrium, so that methanol synthesis is still kinetically controlled. The reaction temperature was varied in steps of 20°C from 260 to 300°C. At each temperature the reaction was carried out for about 20h. An Agilent gas chromatograph equipped with two thermal conductivity detectors using He as carrier gas was used for quantitative online gas analysis. 3 Results 3.1 Characterization of the catalyst The specific surface areas of the calcined, pyrolyzed and reduced catalyst precursors at different temperatures are summarized in Table 1 . The specific surface areas of the samples were found to depend both on the atmosphere used in the thermal pretreatment and the temperature applied. For the samples treated in the same atmosphere, the specific surface areas decrease with increasing temperatures. The change in the specific surface area with increasing thermal treatment temperature is mainly attributed to the sintering of the oxide nanoparticles during the thermal treatment, which leads to the formation of larger particles with higher crystallinity. At the same thermal pretreatment temperature, reduced catalysts always exhibit the highest specific surface areas, while the calcined samples generally have lower specific surfaces area than the pyrolyzed samples: reduction>pyrolysis>calcination. Obviously, the reduced and pyrolyzed samples exhibit higher resistance against sintering. The main reaction during the thermal pretreatment is the decomposition of the hydrotalcite-like precursors releasing H2O and CO2. In the presence of O2 Cr(III) can be partially oxidized forming zinc chromate. It is assumed that rather than the existence of the chromate species, the process of forming these species actually results in the smaller surface area of the samples. Therefore, even at temperatures above 500°C, at which most of chromate species are already decomposed, the calcined samples still exhibit lower surface areas than the reduced and pyrolyzed samples. As shown in Fig. S1, the catalyst precursors obtained via co-precipitation exhibit the characteristic reflections of hydrotalcite-like Zn4Cr2(OH)12CO3, which can no longer be observed after calcination (Fig. 1 ). For the catalyst precursors calcined at 500°C and 600°C, the observed reflections match very well with the characteristic reflections of ZnO and Zn-Cr spinel. The catalyst precursor calcined at 400°C exhibits relatively broad and weak reflections of the ZnO and Zn-Cr spinel phases indicating smaller particle sizes compared with the catalyst precursors calcined at higher temperatures. For the catalyst precursor calcined at 320°C, the very broad reflections suggest that the sample is in an essentially amorphous state. The main component of the amorphous material is assumed to be the Zn-rich non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel. The compositional incompatibility between Zn4Cr2(OH)12CO3 and ZnCr2O4 hinders the formation of pure Zn-Cr spinel phase and causes the typically poorly crystalline mixtures obtained by the thermal treatment [31]. The change in the crystallinity of the sample with increasing calcination temperature is in good agreement with the N2 physisorption results (Table 1). Furthermore, even at high calcination temperatures of 500°C and 600°C, no reflections of Cr2O3 can be observed in the XRD patterns of the calcined samples. Hence, the existence of amorphous or small-sized Cr2O3 is rather unlikely for all samples. It can be proposed that after co-precipitation most of the Cr ions are present in the hydrotalcite-like precursor Zn4Cr2(OH)12CO3. During calcination Zn4Cr2(OH)12CO3 decomposes forming the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel, which is not stable at high temperatures. Thus, high calcination temperatures lead to the destruction of non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel. As the spinel phase is converted to its stoichiometric form, ZnO is segregating from the Zn-Cr spinel lattice. It is also found that this segregation is always accompanied by a change in the lattice parameter of the Zn-Cr spinel phase, which is determined by the quantitative XRD analysis (Table S1). Similar as for the calcined samples, the change in the crystallinity with increasing thermal pretreatment temperature can also be found for the pyrolyzed samples. As shown in Fig. 2 , with increasing pyrolysis temperature from 400°C to 600°C the reflections of both ZnO and Zn-Cr spinel phases become sharper and more intense. However, the samples pyrolyzed at 400°C and 320°C exhibit almost identical XRD patterns, that is, no significant difference in the intensities of the reflections can be observed. The relatively broad reflections indicate that at a pyrolysis temperature of 400°C the samples can still maintain their amorphous state. It is worth noting that for the sample calcined at 400°C, the reflections of both ZnO and Zn-Cr spinel can already be identified, and also the full widths at half maximum (FWHMs) of these reflections are very large. Additionally, compared with the sample calcined at 500°C, the sample pyrolyzed at the same temperature exhibits weaker and broader reflections of the Zn-Cr spinel phase suggesting smaller particle sizes of the Zn-Cr spinel phase in the pyrolyzed samples. As the pyrolysis temperature was raised to 600°C, no obvious difference in intensity of the ZnO and Zn-Cr spinel phases can be seen in comparison to the samples calcined at the same temperature. These observations indicate that for the pyrolysis temperatures in the range from 320°C to 500°C the catalyst shows higher resistance against sintering, especially sintering of the Zn-Cr spinel phase. The change in the intensity of the Zn-Cr spinel phase with increasing thermal treatment temperature is not only caused by the change in the particle size, but also by the destruction of the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel. As a large amount of ZnO is dissolved in the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel, it can exhibit poor crystallinity due to the high concentration of defect sites. During the destruction of the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel, ZnO segregates from the spinel lattice and the Zn-Cr spinel is converted to its stoichiometric form with improved crystallinity. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the pyrolysis in N2 can to some extent inhibit the destruction of the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel caused by high thermal pretreatment temperatures. The XRD patterns of the samples reduced at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 3 . For all the samples, no reflections of other phases than ZnO and Zn-Cr spinel are found. Similar to the pyrolyzed samples with increasing reduction temperature from 400°C to 600°C, a decrease of the FWHMs of the reflections of the ZnO and Zn-Cr spinel phases can be observed, indicating larger particle sizes and higher crystallinity at higher reduction temperatures. Furthermore, after reduction at 320°C and 400°C the samples still remain in an amorphous state. At a reduction temperature of 500°C, the broad reflection located at 2θ=43.8° is the only clearly identifiable reflection of the Zn-Cr spinel phase, while calcined and pyrolyzed samples exhibit the Zn-Cr spinel reflections with relatively smaller FWHM. As the reduction temperature is raised up to 600°C, more well-defined reflections of the Zn-Cr spinel phase can be observed. However, the FWHM of these reflections is clearly larger than that of calcined and pyrolyzed samples thermally treated at the same temperature. By comparing the XRD patterns of the calcined, pyrolyzed and reduced samples treated at the same temperature, it can be concluded that the particle size of the Zn-Cr spinel phase in the samples thermally treated in different atmosphere follows the trend: oxidizing atmosphere>inert atmosphere>reducing atmosphere. Thus, the reduced samples exhibit the highest resistance against the destruction of the Zn-Cr spinel phases caused by high thermal treatment temperatures. This phenomenon can be explained by the chemical mechanism of Zn-Cr spinel formation. According to literature [22,32], the formation of non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel by dissolution of ZnO in normal Zn-Cr spinel also creates oxygen vacancies. At high thermal treatment temperatures, metastable non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel tends to be converted to the stoichiometric form which is thermodynamically more stable. Thermal treatment in an atmosphere with high partial pressures of oxygen can enhance this process by providing the oxygen anions for the re-filling of the oxygen vacancies. Reducing and inert atmospheres with low partial pressure of oxygen favor the formation of oxygen vacancies and, therefore, stabilize the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel. It also needs to be mentioned that the samples reduced at 500°C and 600°C exhibit very intense and sharp reflections of ZnO indicating rapid crystallization of ZnO into large particles. The TPR profiles of the samples calcined at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 4 . A well-defined H2 consumption peak located at around 300°C can be found, which is slightly shifted to lower temperatures with increasing calcination temperature. This single reduction peak has been reported in a number of publications [17,27,28], in which it was assigned to the partial reduction of the Zn-Cr spinel. However, according to the present work, this reduction peak more likely originates from the reduction of chromate species, which are formed by oxidation of Cr3+ during calcination. Since no residual Na is present in the catalyst, these chromate species are assumed to be zinc chromate. It has to be mentioned that both ZnO [33] and Cr2O3 [34,35] require more severe conditions to be reduced, either at higher temperature or higher partial pressures of H2. With increasing calcination temperature, the intensity of the reduction peak at 300°C becomes weaker, indicating a decrease in the total amount of the chromate species. Correspondingly, it has been reported that zinc chromate decompose at 320°C in synthetic air [36]. The results presented here indicate that even at a calcination temperature of 400°C a considerable amount of zinc chromate can still be present in the catalyst. Most of the zinc chromates decomposed at calcination temperatures above 500°C. The broad shoulder reduction maxima at around 350°C for samples calcined at 500°C and 600°C is assumed to be the reduction of intermediate products containing Cr(IV) or Cr(V) formed during decomposition of the zinc chromate. Since the XRD patterns of samples calcined at 500°C and 600°C do not exhibit any reflections of Cr2O3, the main products of the decomposition of zinc chromate are assumed to be ZnO and Zn-Cr spinel. For the samples pyrolyzed at different temperatures (Fig. S2) no sharp and intense reduction peaks located around 300°C were observed as for the calcined samples. This finding indicates that due to the lack of oxidant the formation of zinc chromates is significantly suppressed. Still, a small amount of chromate is believed to be formed in the samples pyrolyzed at 320°C, 400°C and 500°C indicated by the very weak and broad reduction peaks located around 250°C, which are presumably caused by the diffusion of O2 into the tube used during pyrolysis. Interestingly, the samples pyrolyzed at 320°C, 400°C and 500°C additionally exhibit broad reduction peaks, which are approximately located at 576°C, 574°C and 571°C, respectively. Similar results can be observed for the reduced samples (Fig. 5 ). These broad reduction peaks at around 570°C are assumed not to originate from any reduction of chromium ions, because these peaks cannot be found in the TPR profile of the calcined samples. It is very unlikely that the thermal treatments in inert or reducing atmospheres lead to the generation of a species that can be further reduced, while this species cannot even be formed by the thermal treatment in oxidizing atmosphere. According to the FTIR results (Figs. 6 and S3 ), the reduced and pyrolyzed samples show strong carbonate bands, when the temperature of the thermal pretreatment is below 600°C. In addition, all these broad peaks in TPR are located between 500 and 600°C. These observations strongly suggest that these peaks originate from the reduction of high-temperature stable carbonate species present in the reduced and pyrolyzed samples. As shown in Fig. 7 , all calcined samples exhibit a broad and strong band located at 3432cm−1, which is attributed to the stretching vibrations of OH groups. The observed OH groups presumably originate from the presence of adsorbed water, which can be confirmed by the weak and sharp band at 1637cm−1, which is the bending vibration of water. The negative bands at the 2360cm−1 and 2335cm−1 are due to gaseous CO2. The appearance of theses absorption bands is mainly caused by the change of the CO2 concentration in the measuring chamber of the IR spectrometer, in which the sample holder was placed. For the samples calcined at temperature of 320°C and 400°C, the weak bands located at 1508cm−1and 1375cm−1 demonstrate the presence of a small amount of carbonates species in the sample [37]. These bands can no longer be observed in the IR spectra of the samples calcined at 500°C and 600°C, indicating the decomposition of the carbonates species at higher temperature. The composite absorption in the range 850–930cm−1 can be ascribed as the combination of bending and stretching vibrations of Cr(VI)O in zinc chromate [22,37]. Compared with the samples calcined at 320°C and 400°C, the samples calcined at higher temperatures exhibit much weaker bands associated with the chromate species, indicating the partial decomposition of the chromate species at higher calcination temperatures. Correspondingly, the samples calcined at high temperature show smaller reduction peaks of chromates species in the TPR experiments. For samples calcined above 320°C, the bands located at 619cm−1 and 501cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching and bending vibrations of octahedral Cr(III)O in ZnCr spinel [37], respectively. With decreasing calcination temperature, the stretching vibrations of Cr(III)O become weaker and broader. At the calcination temperature of 320°C, only the band originating from the bending spinel vibration can be clearly observed. Based on the XRD and N2 physisorption results, the intensity of the absorption band assigned to the bending vibrations of Cr(III)O seems to depend on the particle size and/or the crystallinity of the ZnCr spinel. It also needs to be mentioned that the assignment of these two principle absorption bands of the ZnCr spinel is controversial. In some publications the band at 619cm−1 was assigned to the ZnO vibration, while the band at 501cm−1 was assigned to CrO [27,38]. These two ZnO and CrO vibration correspond to the intrinsic lattice vibrations of tetrahedral and octahedral coordination in the spinel structure. Furthermore, for samples calcined at 500°C and 600°C, a broad shoulder appears at 441cm−1, which is associated with ZnO [37,39]. The change in the intensity of this band with increasing calcination temperature further confirms the results of the quantitative analysis: at high calcination temperatures non-stoichiometric ZnCr spinel decomposes forming ZnO and stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel. As shown in Figs. S3 and 6, the pyrolyzed and reduced samples exhibit similar IR bands. However, the band associated with the chromate species becomes significantly weaker or completely disappeared in comparison with the calcined samples, which is in good agreement with the TPR results. The band originating from adsorbed water at 1637cm−1 also becomes significantly weaker and broader, indicating that adsorbed water is mainly due to the presence of hygroscopic chromate species. In addition, the samples pyrolyzed or reduced at temperatures below 600°C show intense bands associated with carbonate species. In literature it is also reported that these surface carbonates are more persistent at high thermal treatment temperatures in reduced and pyrolyzed samples than in calcined samples [22]. This observation supports the hypothesis that the observed broad peak at around 570°C in the TPR profiles results from the reduction of the carbonate species in the pyrolyzed and reduced samples. Furthermore, similar to the calcined samples, the dependence of the intensity of the ZnCr spinel band at 619cm−1 on the particle size and/or crystallinity of the Zn-Cr spinel phase can also be found for pyrolyzed and reduced samples. Nevertheless, this band can already be observed for the samples calcined at 400°C, while for the pyrolyzed and reduced samples, this band is detectable at pyrolysis or reduction temperature equal or above 500°C. It is reasonable to assume that the presence of the chromates species is mainly responsible for the acidity of the calcined samples. More specifically, part of the hygroscopic chromates species and/or chromium (VI) oxide can adsorb water forming chromic acid when exposed to air. Besides the chromic acid formed from chromate species in the catalyst, the surface OH groups and the Cr ions exposed at the surface can also contribute to the acidity of the samples. According to the TPR and FTIR results, the amount of chromate species in the catalyst decreases with increasing calcination temperature. As a result, the amount of the formed chromic acid decreases as well, resulting in the decline in the acidity of the calcined samples with increasing calcination temperature. Furthermore, the removal of the surface OH groups at high calcination temperatures can also lead to the decrease in acidity. The SEM images further confirm that reduction of the samples at 600°C leads to the strong crystallization of ZnO, while the Zn-Cr spinel phase is still present as relatively smaller spherical particles. 3.2 Catalytic activity in methanol synthesis All the catalysts were applied in methanol synthesis at 260, 280 and 300°C. The determined carbon balances were between 99.1% and 100.8%. Fig. 10 shows the methanol productivities as a function of reaction temperature of the samples pretreated in synthetic air, N2 and 10% H2 diluted in N2. Since methanol synthesis is exothermic, with increasing reaction temperature the degree of conversion at the thermodynamic equilibrium decreases. However, it can be clearly seen that for all the catalysts, methanol productivity increases with increasing reaction temperature indicating that methanol synthesis is still under kinetic control at the applied reaction temperatures. Furthermore, at the same temperature of thermal pretreatment, the methanol productivity of the catalysts pretreated in different atmosphere follows the trend: reduced catalyst>pyrolyzed catalyst>calcined catalyst. At the reaction temperature of 260°C the most active reduced catalyst exhibits an almost twice higher methanol productivity than the benchmark catalyst calcined at 320°C. Even at higher reaction temperatures, the most active reduced catalyst still shows a significantly higher methanol productivity compared with the benchmark catalyst. The methanol productivity of the calcined catalyst decreases with increasing thermal treatment temperature, whereas for the reduced and pyrolyzed catalysts, the methanol productivity increases with increasing thermal pretreatment temperature. A maximum is achieved at a thermal pretreatment temperature of 500°C, whereas a further increase in temperature of the thermal pretreatment leads to a decline of methanol productivity. Since the applied reaction temperatures are significantly lower than the thermal pretreatment temperatures, the effect of the reducing syngas mixture during the catalytic test on the performance of the calcined and pyrolyzed catalysts is presumably rather low. The changes in phase composition and morphology of the catalyst caused by the thermal pre-treatments in oxidizing and inert atmospheres cannot be easily reversed by the reducing gas atmosphere during the catalytic test. The degrees of CO conversion and the product distributions of the catalysts thermally pretreated in different atmospheres and at different temperatures are summarized in Tables S3–S5. All the calcined catalysts exhibit a similar product distribution, in which the methanol selectivity is between 90% and 95%. However, no direct correlation between methanol selectivity and thermal pretreatment temperature can be found. Due to the high methanol selectivity, CO conversion shows the same trend as methanol productivity, which has already been demonstrated in Fig. 10. The formation of hydrocarbons and higher alcohols also generate water, which can further react with CO forming CO2 and H2 (water gas shift reaction). Hence, it is found that the CO2 selectivity is correlated with the selectivity towards hydrocarbons. According to the results of elemental analysis, no alkali residue was found in the catalysts. Correspondingly, the catalysts exhibit relatively low selectivities to higher alcohols. The degrees of conversion for both pyrolyzed (Table S4) and reduced (Table S5) catalysts follow the same trend as the methanol productivity shown in Fig. 10. In general, with increasing thermal pretreatment temperature both pyrolyzed and reduced catalysts exhibit slightly higher methanol selectivity and lower selectivity towards hydrocarbons and CO2. Additionally, high reaction temperatures lead to an increase in the selectivity to hydrocarbons and CO2 at the expense of methanol selectivity. This observation suggests that the rate of hydrocarbon formation increases more rapidly with increasing reaction temperature in comparison to the methanol formation rate. Furthermore, it can be seen that the reduced catalysts exhibit higher methanol selectivity than the catalyst calcined or pyrolyzed at the same thermal treatment temperature. In summary, the pretreatment in inert and reducing atmosphere at 500°C can substantially improve the performance of ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts applied in methanol synthesis without causing significant deactivation. As shown in Fig. S6 and Table S6, no significant change in methanol yield or methanol selectivity with time on stream can be observed. Furthermore, the deviations between the results of the original test and those of the reproducibility test are within a reasonably small range. 4 Discussion The thermal pretreatments in reducing and inert atmospheres significantly improved the performance of the ZnO/Cr2O3 methanol synthesis catalysts, whereas for catalysts calcined in air higher calcination temperatures lower the catalytic activity. The activity of the pyrolyzed and reduced catalysts is initially enhanced by raising the temperature of the thermal treatment up to 500°C. A further increase in thermal pretreatment temperature to 600°C leads to a decline of the catalytic activity. The specific surface areas of the catalysts pretreated in different atmospheres follow the trend: reduced catalysts>pyrolyzed catalysts>calcined catalysts corresponding to the catalytic test results, but the differences in surface area are not as significant as the differences in catalytic activity. Therefore, the total surface area of the catalyst does not seem to be the sole factor determining the catalytic activity. Previous work proposed the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel to be the active phase on which a thin amorphous ZnO layer is present [29]. According to the characterization results, the Zn-Cr spinel phase in the reduced and pyrolyzed catalyst has a smaller particle size compared with the calcined catalyst. Considering the more pronounced crystallization of ZnO in the reduced catalyst found by XRD and SEM, the actual difference in the surface area of the Zn-Cr spinel phase should be much more significant than the observed difference in the total surface area of the catalysts, because both ZnO and spinel phase contribute to the total surface area of the catalyst. Fig. 11 clearly demonstrates the trend of the Zn-Cr spinel particle size in the catalysts thermally pretreated in different atmospheres: reduced catalyst<pyrolyzed catalyst<calcined catalyst. Furthermore, for all the catalysts high thermal treatment temperature shows a negative effect on the catalyst by causing the sintering of the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel phase, which is the active component of the catalyst. According to the TPR and FTIR results, the calcined catalysts contain higher levels of chromate species formed by oxidation of Cr(III) in the presence of O2 compared with the pyrolyzed and reduced catalysts. The formation of non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel by dissolution of ZnO in stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel can be negatively influenced by the formation of chromates, especially zinc chromate. Although the chromates can decompose at high thermal treatment temperature to form Zn-Cr spinel again, the resulting Zn-Cr spinel with high crystallinity and large particle size is no longer beneficial for the formation of non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel, which means that the formation and subsequent decomposition or reduction of chromates causes unfavorable changes in the morphology and chemical composition of the catalysts. According to the NH3 TPD and FTIR results, the acidity of the catalyst is mainly attributed to the surface OH groups, the Cr3+ ions exposed on the surface, and chromic acid formed from chromate species. The calcined catalysts exhibit higher concentrations of the acid sites than the pyrolyzed and reduced catalysts. The strength of the acid sites in the calcined catalysts is also higher than that in the pyrolyzed and reduced catalysts. The higher surface acidity of the calcined catalyst is obviously due to the higher content of chromate species. It is reported that high surface acidity can lead to the enhancement of undesired hydrocarbon formation [44] or/and the formation of dimethylether [45] depending on the strength of the acid sites. In the present work, the improvement of methanol selectivity observed for the reduced catalysts may result from the lower amount of acid sites and weaker acid strength compared with the calcined catalysts. The presence of carbonate species in the catalysts thermally treated at low temperatures, especially in the pyrolyzed and reduced samples, can be confirmed by FTIR and TPR. The effect of carbonate species on the performance of the catalyst is still not fully clear, but it seems that the presence of carbonate stabilizes the Zn-Cr spinel phase against sintering, and, correspondingly, the calcined catalysts containing a very low amount of carbonate did not show good performance in methanol synthesis. The non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel is assumed to be the active phase in the ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts. DFT simulations revealed that this active component consists of an amorphous ZnO mono- or bilayer supported on the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel which exposes undercoordinated Zn sites. Oxygen vacancies are considered to be the active sites for CO hydrogenation. According to the calculated oxygen vacancy formation energies for the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel [29], the more ZnO is dissolved in the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel, the lower is the energy required for the formation of oxygen vacancies. As a result, the catalyst exhibits a higher activity. In the present work, it is found that the thermal pretreatment can cause the destruction of the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel, which is evidenced by the segregation of the ZnO phase observed in the XRD results. The determination of the lattice parameter of the spinel-like phase by quantitative XRD analysis further confirms the decrease in the unit cell volume with increasing thermal pretreatment temperature, indicating the partial conversion of non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel to its stoichiometric form. The partial destruction of the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel forming bulk ZnO leads to a high formation energy of oxygen vacancies, which can further result in the decrease in catalytic activity. As shown in Table S1, at a thermal pretreatment temperature of 600°C the reduced catalyst exhibits the highest Zn-Cr spinel unit cell volume. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that the reduced catalysts show some resistance against the destruction of non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel. This hypothesis is supported by the maintained broad XRD reflections of the Zn-Cr spinel phase after thermal pretreatment up to 500°C for the reduced catalysts. In general, the gas atmosphere applied can also have a direct positive effect on the formation of oxygen vacancies, which remain stable under the highly reducing methanol synthesis conditions [43,46–48]. Vanheusden et al. [47] thermally treated commercial ZnO powders at different temperatures in oxidizing (pure O2) and reducing (forming gas) atmosphere, respectively. It was found that in reducing atmosphere the concentration of both free carriers and oxygen vacancies increased with increasing annealing temperature up to 800°C, while a completely reverse dependence of the number of oxygen vacancies on the annealing temperature was observed for ZnO treated in oxidizing atmosphere. The formation of oxygen vacancies is basically the partial reduction of ZnO due to the removal of oxygen atoms. Therefore, the presence of reducing agents and low partial pressures of O2 both favor the formation of oxygen vacancies. Photoluminescence (PL) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy are highly suitable techniques for the characterization of oxygen vacancies to be applied in forthcoming studies to the ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts. 5 Conclusions ZnO/Cr2O3 catalysts were synthesized by co-precipitation followed by thermal pretreatments in different gas atmospheres at temperatures in the range from 320°C to 600°C. Compared with the catalysts thermally treated in reducing and inert atmosphere, catalysts calcined in air exhibit lower surface areas. Additionally, calcination in air causes the formation of chromate species, which leads to higher amounts of acid surface sites. In comparison to the calcined catalysts, the reduced and pyrolyzed catalysts contain higher amounts of carbonate species, which seem to be able to stabilize the Zn-Cr spinel phase against sintering. The methanol productivity of the catalyst thermally pretreated at the same temperature follows the trend reduced catalyst˃pyrolyzed catalyst˃calcined catalyst. This trend is closely related to the observed particle size of the Zn-Cr spinel phase. Different dependences of the catalytic activity on the thermal pretreatment temperatures were observed as a function of the atmospheres applied. For catalyst calcined in air, high temperatures lead to smaller surface areas and conversion of the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel into its stoichiometric form by segregation of crystalline ZnO. Correspondingly, the catalytic activity decreases with increasing calcination temperature. Reduced and pyrolyzed catalysts show higher resistance against sintering and the partial destruction of the non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel phase at higher temperatures. Additionally, higher temperatures applied in reduction or pyrolysis of the catalyst precursor can enhance the formation of oxygen vacancies, which are the actual active sites for CO hydrogenation. For reduction/pyrolysis temperatures in the range from 320°C to 500°C, the enhanced formation of oxygen vacancies is identified as the dominating effect. As a result, methanol productivity increases with increasing reduction/pyrolysis temperature. At higher reduction/pyrolysis temperatures the smaller surface area and partial destruction of non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel becomes the dominating effect. Therefore, a decline of methanol productivity can be observed, when the reduction/pyrolysis temperature is further raised to 600°C. coredata.dc:description: Co-precipitated ZnO/Cr2O3 catalyst precursors were thermally pretreated in synthetic air (calcination), N2 (pyrolysis) and 10% H2 diluted in N2 (reduction) at temperatures in the range from 320°C to 600°C and then applied in methanol synthesis from CO and H2 at 260–300°C and 60bar. The X-ray diffraction patterns showed that increasing temperatures used in the thermal pretreatment lead to sintering of both the resulting non-stoichiometric Zn-Cr spinel and ZnO phases. However, reduced and pyrolyzed catalysts exhibit a much slower increase in particle size of the Zn-Cr spinel phase compared with the calcined catalyst. Correspondingly, at the same temperature of thermal pretreatment the specific surface areas of the catalyst follow the trend reduced catalyst>pyrolyzed catalyst>calcined catalyst. Chromate species were found to be present in the calcined catalyst, while their amount decreased with increasing calcination temperature. Infrared spectroscopy and temperature-programmed reduction confirmed the existence of carbonate species in the catalysts reduced or pyrolyzed below 500°C. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption showed that the calcined catalysts exhibit more acid sites due to the existence of chromate species. The reduced and pyrolyzed catalysts demonstrate significantly improved performance in high-temperature methanol synthesis compared with the calcined catalysts, and the maximum methanol productivity was achieved subsequent to reduction at 500°C. It is suggested that the thermal pretreatment in reducing or inert atmosphere favors the formation of oxygen vacancies, which are considered to be the active sites for the hydrogenation of CO.
